question.questionText: John wanted to find the optimum conditions for growing peas. He planted pea seeds in 2 separate pots. He used the same amount and type of soil in each pot. He recorded daily care (amount of water and plant food) and results (plant length and number of leaves) after 2 weeks, as shown in the following chart. Did John do a good job of controlling the variables in his experiment? Explain why or why not.

referenceAnswers.referenceAnswer: No. John changed 2 variables at the same time (amount of water and amount of plant food) so John can not know which variables made a difference.

studentAnswers.studentAnswer: No, Because John changed 2 variables not one. They are Pot A 25 milliliters of water 2 grams of food, Pot B 100 milliliters of water one gram of food.
No, He did no have a controlled experiment.
No, He did not do a good job because he changed 2 variables; water and food.
Yes, It seems to be going fine well.
Yes, Because he did not have Pot B the same as Pot A.
Yes, Because the way he made the chart to stay organized.
No, Because he changed 2 variables.
No, Because he did not control his variables.
No, Because he changed more than one variable; water and plant food.
No, Because he changed 2 variables.
No, Because in Pot A he used 75 milliliters then Pot B had 100 milliliters it is a big difference.
No, He changed the water and the food and to have a controlled experiment you can only change one variable.
No, He does not tell if the plant got sunlight or oxygen.
Yes, Because he did the same thing a scientist would do by jotting down notes.
Yes, Because it is neat, he recorded all plants, and he changed the watered and food to find the plants preferred environment.
